deliberation: Checked vocatives, imperatives, and legal language. Detected (1) geographic term used for distant nations and (2) conceptualization of an international theological dispute as a court case. Considered but did not separate “renew their strength” as its own metaphor since it belongs to the same court-contest frame.

instances.english_text: Stand silent before Me, coastlands
posture: universal summons including the remotest peoples
instances.explanation: “Coastlands” functions as a metonymic/synecdochic way of referring to distant nations in general, not only literal shorelands.

instances.english_text: Let us come forward together for argument / for judgment
target: the theological contest between YHWH and the nations’ gods
ground: formal evaluation, presentation of evidence, rendered verdict
posture: YHWH invites rational evaluation of His claims
instances.explanation: YHWH casts the impending confrontation with the nations and their gods as a court case, a metaphorical ‘trial’ in which arguments are weighed.

deliberation: Looked for comparisons and idioms. Found two explicit כ‑similes describing the ease with which the eastern conqueror reduces nations, and a militarized idiom “call him to his foot” but treated only the clear similes as separate figurative instances.

instances.english_text: Has rendered their swords like dust
target: the defeated nations and their military power
ground: insubstantiality, ease of sweeping away, worthlessness
posture: emphasizing the total collapse of opposition
instances.explanation: The enemy’s swords are said to become “like dust,” comparing their once-deadly power to something weightless and easily scattered; the effect is a hyperbolic simile for complete defeat.

instances.english_text: Their bows [are] like wind‑blown straw
target: the same conquered forces and their offensive capacity
vehicle: light agricultural refuse blown by wind
ground: being easily driven away, offering no resistance, fragility
instances.explanation: The bows of the nations are likened to chaff-like straw driven by the wind, a simile that hyperbolically underscores their utter impotence before the divinely backed victor.

deliberation: The verse describes pursuit and advance “in peace” along a path his feet had not previously trodden. The imagery is mostly literal military movement; I considered whether ‘a path his feet have not come’ is metaphorical for unprecedented success, but it reads more like vivid description than a full metaphor.
Examined divine self‑description. The phrase ‘first and with the last’ functions as a temporal merism for comprehensive sovereignty, not merely sequence. That is the main figurative element here.

instances.english_text: I, GOD, who was first and will be with the last as well
target: YHWH’s eternal existence and sovereign control
ground: encompassing all times, from beginning to end
instances.explanation: Calling Himself ‘first’ and ‘with the last’ uses a meristic metaphor: the endpoints of time express God’s exhaustive, eternal sovereignty.

deliberation: Looked at ‘coastlands’ and ‘ends of the earth’ plus their reactions. Found (1) personification of lands as seeing and fearing, and (2) ‘ends of the earth’ as a merism/synecdoche for the whole world.

instances.hebrew_text: רָאוּ אִיִּים וְיִרָאוּ קְצֹות הָאָרֶץ יֶחֱרָדוּ
instances.english_text: The coastlands look on in fear, the ends of earth tremble
vehicle: ‘coastlands’ and ‘ends of the earth’ as seeing, fearing, trembling subjects
ground: universal human reaction of alarm to God’s acts
attributing human perception and emotion to places
posture: emphasizes universal impact of YHWH’s intervention
instances.explanation: Geographical extremities are personified as seeing, fearing, and trembling; ‘ends of the earth’ also forms a meristic expression for all nations.

deliberation: Describes mutual encouragement among craftsmen. The verbs are literal social actions; no obvious metaphor, simile, or other non‑literal usage stands out here.

The verse vividly describes stages of idol manufacture. Although the whole scene contributes to prophetic irony in the larger unit, within this verse the actions (‘smooths,’ ‘pounds,’ ‘fixes with nails’) are literal craft operations, not figurative expressions.

Examined covenant designations. ‘Israel my servant’ is a relational metaphor (nation as servant of a king). ‘Seed of Abraham’ is basically genealogical; ‘friend’ is relational but not strongly figurative here. Main figurative element is the servant metaphor.

instances.english_text: But you, Israel, My servant
target: the nation Israel in its covenant role
vehicle: a loyal servant of a great lord or king
ground: belonging to a master, obligation to obey, being under protection and authority
posture: reassuring Israel of chosen, protected status
instances.explanation: Israel is called ‘my servant,’ a metaphor framing the people’s identity as that of a royal servant under YHWH’s authority and care.

deliberation: Looked especially at spatial phrases. ‘Ends of the earth’ functions as a merism for the total dispersion from which God draws Israel, while the rest of the verse is largely literal covenant language.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר הֶחֱזַקְתִּיךָ מִקְצֹות הָאָרֶץ וּמֵאֲצִילֶיהָ קְרָאתִיךָ
instances.english_text: You whom I drew from the ends of the earth and called from its far corners
ground: maximal dispersion and God’s reach everywhere
comprehensive scope of God’s choosing and gathering
posture: assuring Israel of God’s far‑reaching choice and grasp
instances.explanation: ‘Ends’/‘corners’ of the earth is a meristic way to say ‘from everywhere,’ underscoring God’s comprehensive gathering of His people.

deliberation: Attended to anthropomorphic expressions. ‘Uphold you with my righteous right hand’ uses the ‘hand’ as a metonymy for God’s power and support; ‘uphold’ itself is metaphorical for protecting and sustaining.

instances.english_text: I uphold you with My victorious right hand
target: God’s protective and saving action toward Israel
vehicle: a ‘right hand’ that holds and supports
limb of a powerful warrior/king (metonymy for strength)
instances.explanation: God’s ‘right hand’ stands metonymically for His power; ‘upholding’ is a metaphor for His sustaining and protecting Israel.

deliberation: The core figurative element is the comparison of adversaries to ‘nothing’ (כְאַיִן); shame vocabulary is literal. I treat the ‘like nothing’ constructions as similes with hyperbolic force.

instances.english_text: They shall become as naught
ground: complete loss of power and significance, practical nonexistence
instances.explanation: Adversaries are compared to ‘nothing,’ a hyperbolic simile that portrays their destined insignificance and powerlessness.

deliberation: Again, key figurative language is the double comparison ‘like nothing and like nonexistence.’ The searching and not finding could be literal outcome; the simile intensifies the idea of utter nullification.

instances.english_text: Less than nothing shall be the men who battle against you
target: those who wage war against Israel
ground: absolute lack of power, presence, or significance
instances.explanation: Warring men are said to become ‘like nothing and nonexistence,’ a doubled hyperbolic simile stressing their total nullification.

deliberation: Focused on anthropomorphic imagery. ‘Who grasped your right hand’ is a relational metaphor (and metonymy) portraying God as literally taking Israel’s hand like a helper or parent.

instances.english_text: Who grasped your right hand
target: God’s intimate help and guidance of His people
posture: tender, reassuring depiction of God’s help
instances.explanation: God is pictured as grasping Israel’s right hand, a bodily image and metonymy for His close, guiding and supporting help.

deliberation: The striking phrase is ‘worm Jacob,’ clearly metaphorical for Israel’s weakness and lowliness. ‘Redeemer’ is also metaphorical (legal-kin role), but ‘worm’ is the dominant vivid image here.

instances.english_text: Fear not, O worm Jacob
target: the nation Israel in its humiliated condition
ground: frailty, insignificance, easy to crush, contemptibility
posture: acknowledging Israel’s lowliness while promising help
instances.explanation: Israel is metaphorically called a ‘worm,’ highlighting its vulnerability and insignificance in human eyes, in contrast to God’s pledged help.

deliberation: This verse is thick with agricultural and topographical imagery. Detected (1) Israel-as-threshing‑sledge metaphor, and (2) explicit simile ‘hills like chaff,’ with the intervening ‘thresh mountains’ as part of that same threshing metaphor plus hyperbole.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה שַׂמְתִּיךְ לְמוֹרַג חָרוּץ חָדָשׁ בַּעַל פִּיפִיּוֹת
instances.english_text: I will make of you a threshing board, a new thresher, with many spikes
target: Israel as an instrument of God’s judgment and victory
vehicle: מוֹרַג חָרוּץ חָדָשׁ בַּעַל פִּיפִיּוֹת ‘a sharp new threshing sledge with many teeth’
ground: capacity to crush and separate, efficiency and sharpness, effectiveness in destroying what is threshed
being used powerfully to break down opposition
posture: dramatically revaluing feeble Israel as powerful tool
instances.explanation: Israel is metaphorically turned into a spiked threshing-sledge, portraying the people as God’s powerful instrument for pulverizing opposition.

instances.hebrew_text: תָּד֤וּשׁ הָרִים וְתָדֹק וּגְבָעוֹת כַּמֹּץ תָּשִׂים
instances.english_text: You shall thresh mountains to dust, and make hills like chaff
vehicle: mountains and hills treated as grain reduced to dust and chaff
ground: crushing what seems massive, reducing to weightless residue, ease of disposal
overwhelming victory over seemingly immovable forces
posture: hyperbolically assuring invincibility by God’s power
instances.explanation: The ‘mountains’ and ‘hills’ representing great powers are said to be threshed and turned into ‘chaff,’ a hyperbolic simile expressing the total shattering of what seems solid and imposing.

deliberation: Continues the threshing imagery. ‘Winnow them and the wind shall carry them off; the whirlwind shall scatter them’ portrays enemies like chaff removed by wind. This is one extended metaphor rooted in agricultural practice.

instances.hebrew_text: תִּזְרֵם וְרוּחַ תִּשָּׂאֵם וּסְעָרָה תָּפִיץ אוֹתָם
instances.english_text: You shall winnow them and the wind shall carry them off; the whirlwind shall scatter them
vehicle: winnowed chaff blown away by wind and storm
separated husks removed by air currents
ground: being weightless, unable to resist, quickly and completely removed
posture: celebrating the completeness of God-given victory
instances.explanation: Enemies are implicitly treated as chaff that is winnowed and blown away by wind and storm, a hyperbolic threshing metaphor for their utter removal.

deliberation: Considered whether the thirst imagery is literal or figurative. Even if physical need is in view, ‘their tongue is parched with thirst’ is a vivid hyperbolic image focusing on the organ of speech as a metonymy for the whole person’s desperate condition.

instances.english_text: Their tongue is parched with thirst
target: the poor and needy in extreme deprivation
vehicle: a dried-out tongue failing from thirst
desiccated body part as symptom of near-death thirst
ground: intense lack of life‑sustaining resources, weakness, inability even to speak
posture: highlighting the severity of need as backdrop to God’s care
instances.explanation: The tongue is singled out as dried by thirst, a metonymic and hyperbolic way of portraying the people’s extreme, life‑threatening deprivation.

deliberation: The language of rivers on bare heights and desert turned to pools could be literal miraculous imagery, but in Deutero‑Isaiah it consistently serves as a metaphor for comprehensive restoration. I treat the cluster as one transformation metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶפְתַּח עַל־שְׁפָיִים נְהָרוֹת ... אָשִׂים מִדְבָּר לַאֲגַם־מַיִם וְאֶרֶץ צִיָּה לְמוֹצָאֵי מָיִם
instances.english_text: I will open up streams on the bare hills … I will turn the desert into ponds, the arid land into springs of water
target: Israel’s devastated, needy condition and its future restoration
vehicle: barren heights and desert transformed into abundant waters
landscape changing from arid to well‑watered
ground: reversal from barrenness to abundance, life‑giving refreshment, unexpected fertility
total change of fortunes and conditions
instances.explanation: The transformation of desert into pools and springs functions as a metaphor for God’s radical renewal of His people’s condition.

deliberation: Imagery is of exotic, valuable trees planted in wilderness and desert. In this prophetic context it points beyond literal forestry to metaphorical flourishing in a once-barren place.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶתֵּן בַּמִּדְבָּר אֶרֶז שִׁטָּה וַהֲדַס וְעֵץ שָׁמֶן ... בָּעֲרָבָה בְּרֹושׁ תִּדְהָר וּתְאַשּׁוּר יַחְדָּו
instances.english_text: I will plant cedars in the wilderness, acacias and myrtles and oleasters; I will set cypresses in the desert, box trees and elms as well
target: the renewed, beautified community and land of Israel
state of God’s people after salvation
vehicle: luxuriant, diverse trees thriving in wilderness/desert
ground: beauty, stability, long life, abundance where none was expected
posture: depicting restoration as lush and superabundant
instances.explanation: The planting of valuable trees in desert regions metaphorically represents God’s lavish restoration and beautification of His people and land.

deliberation: Key figurative element is ‘GOD’s hand has done this,’ where ‘hand’ stands metonymically for God’s power/effective action.

instances.english_text: That GOD’s hand has done this
target: God’s effective intervention and creative work
ground: agency, capability, power to bring about effects
concrete expression of might and initiative
posture: directing observers to attribute events to YHWH alone
instances.explanation: ‘Hand of GOD’ is a metonymy for His power and effective agency in bringing about the promised transformation.

deliberation: Again draws on courtroom language: ‘Submit your case’ and ‘Offer your pleas’ frame the dispute with idols and their worshipers as a lawsuit. This is the same legal metaphor seen already in v.1 but here applied explicitly to the idols’ advocates.

instances.english_text: Submit your case … Offer your pleas
target: the theological claim of the idols and their worshipers
vehicle: a legal ‘case’ and ‘pleas’ presented in court
ground: formal presentation and testing of claims, demand for evidence and reasoning
posture: challenging idols to prove themselves under scrutiny
instances.explanation: The prophetic challenge is cast as a court case, a metaphor that pictures the contest between YHWH and the idols as a lawsuit requiring evidence.

deliberation: Verse invites the idols to report past and future events; the language of telling, happening, and outcomes is straightforward. No clear metaphor, simile, or other classic figure appears here beyond the already-established court frame from the previous verse.
The command to idols, ‘Do anything, good or bad, that we may be awed and see,’ is ironic: the speaker knows they can do nothing. This is rhetorical irony, not literal expectation of action.

instances.english_text: Do anything, good or bad, that we may be awed and see
target: the supposed powers of the idols
vehicle: gods performing good or evil deeds before observers
ground: (negated) capacity to effect real outcomes; expectation versus reality
contrast between claimed divinity and actual impotence
instances.explanation: The invitation for idols to ‘do good or bad’ so people may be amazed is ironic: it personifies the idols as if they could act, precisely to expose that they cannot.

deliberation: ‘You are less than nothing, your effect is less than nullity’ portrays the idols and their works with ontological negation. This is figurative—metaphorical and hyperbolic—language of worthlessness.

instances.english_text: Why, you are less than nothing, your effect is less than nullity
target: the idols and their supposed works
ground: complete lack of real power, value, or effect
posture: denouncing idolatry in the strongest terms
instances.explanation: Idols and their works are described as ‘from nothing’ and ‘from nullity,’ a metaphoric and hyperbolic way to say they have no real existence or efficacy.

deliberation: The conqueror’s treatment of rulers is compared twice: ‘like mud’ and ‘like a potter treading clay.’ These are explicit כ‑similes expressing ease and thoroughness of subjugation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָבֹא סְגָנִים כְּמוֹ־חֹמֶר וּכְמוֹ יוֹצֵר יִרְמַס־טִיט
instances.english_text: He has trampled rulers like mud, like a potter treading clay
target: princes/rulers subjected by the eastern/northern conqueror
vehicle: mud and clay trampled underfoot by a potter
ground: being underfoot, easily controlled, reshaped or crushed, lacking resistance
posture: emphasizing the conqueror’s overwhelming, almost effortless power
instances.explanation: Rulers are likened to mud or potter’s clay underfoot, similes that hyperbolically convey their complete subjugation and humiliation.

deliberation: This is a rhetorical question about foretelling events. All core terms (‘foretold,’ ‘announced,’ ‘heard’) are used literally; I did not detect separate metaphors or similes beyond the legal-contest frame already established.

‘I send a herald to Jerusalem’ could be either literal messenger or metonymic for the prophetic message. But the verse as worded does not clearly employ a distinct figurative image; it is straightforward announcement language.

God’s looking and finding ‘no man’ and ‘no counselor’ refers to the utter lack of competent responders among the idols or their spokesmen. In context this appears literal, not exaggeration; no separate metaphor or simile is formed.

The closing verdict on the idols contains several evaluative metaphors: ‘all are nothing, their works are nullity, their molten images are wind and chaos.’ The most vivid figure is ‘wind and tohu’ for their images, which I treat as the primary metaphor, with ‘nothing / nullity’ as supporting expressions.

instances.english_text: Their statues are naught and nil / wind and confusion
target: the idols’ images and what they represent
ground: lack of solidity, instability, meaninglessness, futility
having no real substance or ordered reality behind appearances
posture: contemptuously dismissing idols as utterly empty
instances.explanation: The metal images are said to be ‘wind and chaos,’ a metaphor (with hyperbolic force) representing them as insubstantial and meaningless.
